list_definition.definition: to tell (about something) before it has happened

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Astrologers claim to be able to foretell the future from the stars.

list_ex_of_english: In other words, if they are thinking ideologically, from a more or less coherent belief system, their left-right seven-point scale position will foretell their issue position.
Employers had always known that some employees were more desirable than others, and that knowledge made many of them ready for the articulated insight that accident records foretold more accidents.
These developments foretold what would develop from the late 1880s onward.
In their modernist drives, the tragic ends of these tales foretold future happy endings.
But if we do not allow her to do so there are those who foretell that continuing and remorseless decline of the economy.
And the darkened tones around it foretell that her lover's downfall will be linked to how he treats this symbolic beast.
Ecosystems do not follow a series of deterministic replacements that can be foretold from physical parameters: rather they jump from one state to another.
When that programme was enunciated in 1945, could it be foretold that the international situation would deteriorate to the level it has reached now?
